Package com.github.yellowstonegames.glyph

Class GlyphMap

java.lang.Object
com.github.yellowstonegames.glyph.GlyphMap
public class GlyphMap extends Object
Stores a sparse map of (unmoving) glyphs by their positions, as well as a dense grid of background colors, and allows this group of chars and colors to be drawn easily. Glyphs are represented by long values, and are handled by a Font (which this also stores) to get a char, foreground color, and a variety of possible styles for each glyph. A GlyphMap also stores a Viewport, which defaults to a StretchViewport but can be changed easily; this viewport affects what region of the GlyphMap is drawn. You typically call one of the draw(Batch, float, float) methods in your rendering code every frame, some time after clearing the screen. There are draw() overloads that only render a subregion of the GlyphMap; one uses a Frustum (almost always from Camera.frustum) to draw only visible glyphs and backgrounds, while another takes a specific rectangular area of cells. You should call resize(int, int) in your application's or screen's resize code, because it keeps the viewport accurate.

  • Constructor Details

    • GlyphMap

      public GlyphMap()
      Constructs a bare-bones GlyphMap with size 64x64. Does not set font, you will have to set it later.

    • GlyphMap

      public GlyphMap(com.github.tommyettinger.textra.Font font)
      Constructs a 64x64 GlyphMap with the specified Font. You probably want GlyphMap(Font, int, int) unless your maps are always 64x64.
      Parameters:
      font - a Font that will be copied and used for the new GlyphMap

    • GlyphMap

      public GlyphMap(com.github.tommyettinger.textra.Font font, int gridWidth, int gridHeight)
      Constructs a GlyphMap with the specified size in cells wide and cells tall for its grid, using the specified Font (which will be copied).
      Parameters:
      font - a Font that will be copied and used for the new GlyphMap
      gridWidth - how many cells wide the grid should be
      gridHeight - how many cells tall the grid should be

  • Method Details

    • getRgba

      public static int getRgba(String description)
      This is mostly here to help ColorLookup get RGBA8888 colors from valid descriptions, or null from invalid ones.
      Parameters:
      description - a color description, as a lower-case String matching the format covered in DescriptiveColor.describe(CharSequence)
      Returns:
      an Integer that either contains an RGBA8888 color (if description was valid) or null otherwise

    • getFont

      public com.github.tommyettinger.textra.Font getFont()

    • setFont

      public void setFont(com.github.tommyettinger.textra.Font font)
      Sets the Font this uses, but also configures the viewport to use the appropriate size cells, then scales the font to size 1x1 (this makes some calculations much easier inside GlyphMap).
      Parameters:
      font - a Font that will be used directly (not copied) and used to calculate the viewport dimensions

    • getGridWidth

      public int getGridWidth()
      Gets how wide the grid is, measured in discrete cells.
      Returns:
      how many cells wide the grid is

    • getGridHeight

      public int getGridHeight()
      Gets how high the grid is, measured in discrete cells.
      Returns:
      how many cells high the grid is

    • fuse

      public static int fuse(int x, int y)
      Combines the up-to-15-bit non-negative ints x and y into one non-negative result int. This is used to get the keys for a GlyphMap given x,y inputs. Because jdkgdxds uses Fibonacci hashing to scramble keys, there's no concern here from leaving all of x in the lower half of the bits and all of y in the upper half.
      Parameters:
      x - an up-to-15-bit non-negative int (between 0 and 32767, inclusive)
      y - an up-to-15-bit non-negative int (between 0 and 32767, inclusive)
      Returns:
      a non-negative int that combines x and y into one value

    • fuse

      public static int fuse(com.github.yellowstonegames.grid.Coord xy)
      Combines the up-to-15-bit non-negative x and y components of the Coord xy into one non-negative result int. This is used to get the keys for a GlyphMap given x,y inputs. Because jdkgdxds uses Fibonacci hashing to scramble keys, there's no concern here from leaving all of x in the lower half of the bits and all of y in the upper half.
      Parameters:
      xy - a Coord with non-negative x and y
      Returns:
      a non-negative int that combines the Coord's x and y into one value

    • extractX

      public static int extractX(int fused)
      Given a fused x,y pair as an int (typically produced by fuse(int, int)), this gets the x component from it, as an int.
      Parameters:
      fused - a fused x,y pair as an int as produced by fuse(int, int)
      Returns:
      the x component of fused

    • extractY

      public static int extractY(int fused)
      Given a fused x,y pair as an int (typically produced by fuse(int, int)), this gets the y component from it, as an int.
      Parameters:
      fused - a fused x,y pair as an int as produced by fuse(int, int)
      Returns:
      the y component of fused

    • put

      public void put(int x, int y, int codepoint)
      Places a character (optionally with style information) at the specified cell, using white foreground color.
      Parameters:
      x - x position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      y - y position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      codepoint - the character, with or without style information, to place

    • put

      public void put(int x, int y, int codepoint, int color)
      Places a character (optionally with style information) at the specified cell, using the given foreground color.
      Parameters:
      x - x position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      y - y position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      codepoint - the character, with or without style information, to place
      color - the RGBA8888 color to use for the character

    • put

      public void put(int x, int y, char simpleChar, int color)
      Places a character (optionally with style information) at the specified cell, using the given foreground color.
      Parameters:
      x - x position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      y - y position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      simpleChar - the character, without style information, to place
      color - the RGBA8888 color to use for the character

    • put

      public void put(int x, int y, long glyph)
      Places a glyph (optionally with style information and/or color) at the specified cell.
      Parameters:
      x - x position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      y - y position of the cell, measured in cells on the grid
      glyph - the glyph to place, as produced by Font.markupGlyph(char, String, ColorLookup)

    • put

      public void put(int fused, long glyph)
      Places a glyph (optionally with style information and/or color) at the specified cell (given as a fused value). This put() method has the least overhead if you already have a fused int key and long glyph.
      Parameters:
      fused - a fused x,y position, as produced by fuse(int, int)
      glyph - the glyph to place, as produced by Font.markupGlyph(char, String, ColorLookup)

    • draw

      public void draw(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch batch, float x, float y)
      Draws the entire GlyphMap at the given x,y for its lower-left corner. Does no clipping.
      Parameters:
      batch - a SpriteBatch, usually; must at least be compatible with SpriteBatch's attributes
      x - x of the lower-left corner, in world units
      y - y of the lower-left corner, in world units

    • draw

      public void draw(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch batch, float x, float y, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Frustum limit)
      Draws part of the GlyphMap at the given x,y for its lower-left corner. Still iterates through all keys in order, but only draws those that are visible in the given Frustum limit.
      Parameters:
      batch - a SpriteBatch, usually; must at least be compatible with SpriteBatch's attributes
      x - x of the lower-left corner, in world units
      y - y of the lower-left corner, in world units
      limit - a Frustum, usually obtained from Camera.frustum, that delimits what will be rendered

    • draw

      public void draw(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch batch, float x, float y, int startCellX, int startCellY, int endCellX, int endCellY)
      Draws part of the GlyphMap at the given x,y for its lower-left corner. Only draws cells between startCellX (inclusive) and endCellX (exclusive), and likewise for startCellY and endCellY, where those ints represent cell positions and not screen or world positions. This only even considers keys that are in the given start-to-end rectangle, and doesn't check keys or values outside it. This is probably the most efficient of the draw() methods here, but requires you to know what the start and end bounds are.
      Parameters:
      batch - a SpriteBatch, usually; must at least be compatible with SpriteBatch's attributes
      x - x of the lower-left corner, in world units
      y - y of the lower-left corner, in world units
      startCellX - the inclusive x of the lower-left corner, measured in cells, to start rendering at
      startCellY - the inclusive y of the lower-left corner, measured in cells, to start rendering at
      endCellX - the exclusive x of the upper-right corner, measured in cells, to stop rendering at
      endCellY - the exclusive y of the upper-right corner, measured in cells, to stop rendering at

    • resize

      public void resize(int screenWidth, int screenHeight)
      This should generally be called in the ApplicationListener.resize(int, int) or Screen.resize(int, int) method when the screen size changes. This affects the viewport only.
      Parameters:
      screenWidth - the new screen width in pixels
      screenHeight - the new screen height in pixels
